body.p:
In compliance with your request and indeed
I consider it no more than a duty on my part towards you to acquaint
you that on Monday afternoon last I received yr. Packet a letter from Mr. H.
Feby 5th: I have very little time left on my hands now, I must most fervently pray
and entreat you to excuse haste and writing, as I have been so very
busy this day; in other duties and replying to Mr. H. that it is approaching to Hebrew
but I will give you some little extracts of his letter for your guidance Trusting
to your honor and integrity that you will not make use of my name neither
in this case, or in the other of M. for heaven be my witness that there is no harm?
but dont wish my name in question since we have all some good friends always
on the look out. therefore my Dr. friend let it be Hebrew the information is for
your guidance at the same time I assure you from the 1st syllable to the last
there is not one disrespectful to you, on the contrary he speaks high—where
I said to him in my letter he replies that none should be revered unless for
high moral & religious diligency" "a man in holy office should be raised &
not lowered—he replies, "no removal has taken place—that nothing has been
done to lower our former Hazan in the estimation of the world indeed—and
so Mr. H goes on replying on my remarks—than he goes on informing me
I may say, almost the same as you did in your first letter. I will go on now with fewer traits
"In the first place not a person in the whole congregation says or can
say aught against Mr. Leeser's reputation."—I flattered myself
that I was and that Mr Leeser also considered me his friend—

I feel satisfied that the congregation will not again find a person
combining all the qualities of a Hazan and lecturer and possessing
the talents of Mr. Leeser and no one desires or can detract from his
merits he has done more for the Jews in America than any other

Hazan in these United States and a testimonial &c &c
"but I fear he has gone too far to heal the asperity of feeling with
which he has spoken of so many of the members since he has
ceased to be our Hazan." so far for the extracts I replied to
his obliging letter on every point that I would not arrogate on
me the office of a Judge, and indeed was I asked to form a just
intimate of the subject I should hear both sides Hebrew I was
an advocate for moderation & a reconciliation that I considered you an
honor to the house of Israel at large not only in America and you
have been Hebrew and that after 20 years in office that the
misunderstanding between you and the congregation should be within a
nut shell (as he expresses it) I could not but regard not only with
regret but as a calamity I entertained the hope that he would continue his
kind regards towards you and so on. I must shorten my letter but I
think you have enough of it, it appears that they are exasperated
at your exposing them in the Occident, I hope it will all be peace
yet. Let me once more as a brother, friend, reccomend you give in a little
and hope you will be restored which will be the happiest news you
will give me. Again let me request your secrecy particularly what
I might have wrote of M. as it is only true, but still as he is a friend and
a good young man I dont wish him to know that nay thing about him was
utterd by me Hebrew I also must acquaint you that Mr. H. knows nothing of
your having informed me all in your first letter so let it stand as it is,
please to favor me with your reply and that matters have taken a favorable
change. M. sets off on Saturday next from Liverpool you will please to let

know if you have seen Mr. H. I must confess that his letter is of a ?
and that his feelings are respectful towards you. Wishing you every success

I must add that I wrote to Mr. H. that as
"since my first reading your works I entertaind
the highest respect for your name" the greatest esteem". I believe I did my duty towards
you as much as a father, now you must do the same towards me as a son take
my advice dont be too hard get Mr. H. your friend again, give in a little, and dont
allow your opponents to have their way, I wish I was there to impress all this on your
mind for it is only Hebrew abandon this for a while Hebrew
